content.description: Blocky start just right of Black Mamba.  Tricky start, small pro early in climb.  Crux at first corner. Some loose rock in upper third on easier terrain.
content.protection: Starts with small cams, nuts at tips or smaller.  Hand sized pieces above in easier terrain. Two bolt anchor.
content.location: Just upstream of Black Mamba corner

content.description:
Start at overhanging face to right handed layaway.  Move through blocks to short corner.  Step out on to arête and follow pockets to ring anchor. 

  Gil Scott Heron RIP 

youtube.com/watch?v=otwkXZ0…
content.protection: 6 bolts, ring anchors (can be reached from top)
content.location: Second route on upper tier

content.description: Open book on nice red rock.  Easy moves to ledge (some loose stuff here), then harder climbing through third and forth bolts but well protected.  Small wires could protect these moves (bad fall potential).  Upper wall pocketed and fun.
content.protection: 5 bolts to ring anchors.
content.location: First climb at downstream segment of upper tier.

content.description: Short powerful route on excellent basalt.
content.protection: Four bolts to a two-bolt anchor.
content.location: Just left of "Man who brought the Gear".

content.description: Start at right of Welcome to Utopia on nice in cut right hand rail.  High first bolt protects move to dirty ledge.  Thin crimps sequence to pocketed face.  Traverse to anchors for "Welcome",
content.protection: 5 bolts to anchor at left.
content.location: Fourth route on upper tier.

content.description:
This week we witnessed the 9.0 earthquake and tsunami that followed on northern Honshu in Japan. 

  Boulder start is crux past stick clip bolt.  We used undercling at right to get high foot on right to balance move to horizontal below bolt. Crux continues up to ledge.
content.protection: Stick clip first high bolt. Then 2 more bolts to corner crack.  Protects well with purple, green and red camalots.
content.location: Second route from start of upper tier.

climbs.name: Thin Places
climbs.fa: Mike Howard, Bob D'Antonio, Dan Brockway

content.description:
Offwidth, protects with large gear but can be run out (easy ground) with hand sized pieces. 

travel.nytimes.com/2012/03/…

thinplaces.net/openingartic…
content.protection: I used my #6, #5 and #4. Standard rack will work with creative placements, back cleaning and runouts.  Gear anchor or lean out to chains on Mamba.
content.location: Just right of Black Mamba in dark spillover corner.

content.description: Tips crack to plated face (loose/crumbly).  Tricky stemming problem at base on nice rock, the climbing above is less interesting.
content.protection: 4 bolts, thin hand piece at bottom (green or red Camalot). 2 bolt anchor, no chains easily accessed from top.
content.location: Just where upper trail passed through boulder field

content.description:
Start in sparse finger corner to powerful roof with stemming crux up high to slab exit.  Finish in easier trad crack to anchor. Very gymnastic and sequential, hard onsight for grade.  

Smoke Signals(film) with Sherman Alexie, Native American author and twice winner of the Taos Poetry Slam.
content.protection: 3 bolts low with optional green camalot after first bolt in nice horizontal.  Third bolt hidden above roof to protect exit. Finger to hand size pieces above roof.   2 bolt ring anchor.
content.location: Upper tier upstream bench.  Start under large lichen covered roof with 2 bolts and short finger crack.

content.description:
Start on blocky column to large detached flake in corner, felt solid.  Wind up through either corner to anchor.  Difficult and suspect protection.  GUOS.

 The pyrocumulonimbus cloud (pyroCb) is a type of cumulus cloud formed above a source of heat such as a wildfire and may sometimes even extinguish the fire that formed it. It is the most extreme manifestation of pyrocumulus. According to the American Meteorological Societys Glossary of Meteorology, a pyrocumulus is "a cumulus cloud formed by a rising thermal from a fire, or enhanced by buoyant plume emissions from an industrial combustion process.". Unreal example was visible over Los Alamos due to the Las Conchas plume.
content.protection: Standard rack.
content.location: Left of Smoke Signals

content.description:
Crux passing first bolt then again finishing at chains. Traverse to turn roof on left. 

Oppie
content.protection: 6 bolts to chain anchors.
content.location: Sart in corner left of Modest Mouse.

climbs.name: One Chance... To Get Everything Right

content.description: The crux is getting over the roof and onto the steep slab. Classic, short basalt route.
content.protection:
Four bolts plus a green camalot for the upper crack.  

  Two bolt anchor.
content.location: Start just right of Aldous. Stick clip the first bolt.

content.description: This thing will slap you back.  Crux in shallow corner moving past 2nd bolt.  Nice rock to start turns to featured mudstone above.
content.protection: 6 bolts to ring anchors. ”Deadwood Dick“ would sling a six shooter en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nat_L…
content.location: 50 feet left of Black Mamba.  Start on high incut jug, to small  left alcove.  Next move out into shallow corner crux.

content.description: Left of Black Mamba.  Monkeywrench your way around the pinned horn to reach slab and move behind arete to alcove.  Powerful and technical roof (small undercling to layaway finger lock) up to excellent pocketed face.  Varied and interesting climbing on nice rock.
content.protection: 7 bolts to ring anchors.  Bring a friend who has your back.  Thanks HayD'uke
content.location: Immediately left of black mamba.

content.description:
Monarch is to right on the short grassy  bench.  Named for the cloud of migrating monarch butterflies riding the spring winds south to north along the canyon rim. 

  Upstream of I Came As A Rat.
content.protection: .3 to #2 Camalots.  Wired stoppers also useful. Great warm-up/beginner lead.  Easily Toproped. 2 Bolt Chain Anchors
content.location:
Upper tier upstream. Be careful of climbers on lower tier routes, any rocks rolled could go off the lip below. 

  Monarch butterflies migrate back north from Mexico each spring.  I know exactly what happens to the dotted line of monarchs.  They fly along the rim with the winds in spring.

learner.org/jnorth/monarch/

fs.fed.us/monarchbutterfly/…

monarchwatch.org/tagmig/pea…

content.description: The crux is painful flaring off-size fingers.
content.protection: Small to medium cams. May want one to two each purple and green camalots. Two bolt anchor.
content.location: The very obvious flare crack that faces downriver.

content.description: Short broken corner with finger layaway to ledge.  Follow up nice rock with marginal pro to walk off. Onsite, ground up, sketch fest.
content.protection: Camalots up to blue.  Sit belay behind top boulders by trail.
content.location: First climb on upper tier.

content.description: Short stiff fingers from start in the obvios left facing 20 ft. corner, then hard move above stance to exit left.  GUOS.
content.protection: Purple thru Gold Camalots, double Red useful, medium wires. No Anchor, build one in higher boulders. Walk off top.
content.location: Right of Black Mamba about 70 feet.

climbs.name: The Man... Who Killed The Deer!

content.description: Bouldering moves right off the ground. Getting past the second bolt is the crux. Good climbing above with good gear.
content.protection: Small to medium gear plus four bolts.
content.location: Start just left of "Aldous".

content.description: Bouldering start...leads to cool climbing above. A little loose rock below the upper section, be careful.
content.protection: Five clips and a green Camalot. Lower from a two-bolt anchor.
content.location: On the left side of the wall at a obvious hanging flake.

content.description:
Scramble up easy rock for 12 feet to reach a fun (but much too short) wide fingers corner that is best tackled via laybacking to a decent ledge. Continue up steeper but positive climbing in the shallow corner to the top. Watch your head on the piñon tree branches at the top. 

  The route protects very well and is not very sustained so it would make for a very good beginner gear lead.
content.protection:
Small to medium SLCDs and a rack of nuts.  The tree at the top serves as a good anchor. The route protects very well and is not very sustained so it would make for a very good beginner gear lead.  

  Rap from 2 bolt anchor next to tree.
content.location:
Start approximately 80 feet right of We All Float On just to the right of a big roof. The tree at the top is a good landmark. There's a good chance a flat rock with the number "7" spelled out using tiny little rocks is at the base.  

  Note that we *think* this route is left of Man in the Arena but we didn't find that route so we're not completely sure.  Just look for the big roof and tree and you'll be there.

content.description: 2 Bolts for technical moves through slanting finger crack leads to easy trad climbing.
content.protection: 2 bolts, a few finger to hand sized cams to ring anchors
content.location: Just beyond short boulder field along upper trail.

climbs.name: The Good Times... Are Killing Me!

content.description: The crux is getting over the small roof and onto the steep headwall. Classic route, cool moves on great basalt.
content.protection: Six clips will get you to a two bolt anchor.
content.location: Fifteen feet left of Black Mamba.

content.description:
"Y" crack just below entrance climb down.  Start in alcove below first bolt. Direct start bouldery 5.11 move.  Alternate easier layaway start at left.  Both reach second bolt in shallow corner.  Crux at overhanging finger section to stance at chains.   

rastafarispeaks.com/cgi-bin…

news.nationalgeographic.com…
content.protection: Camalots from purple up to blue.  Double green useful but not necessary.
content.location: First climb.

content.description: Just like the debt ceiling debate, this thing should have been easier that it ended up being.  Bolted left facing corner made possible with large mailslot jug at right wall.  This crux leads to a leftward traverse at 3rd bolt.   stay low and avoid blocky exit to right.  Continue to second crux at upper corner then to 2 bolt anchor.
content.protection: 6 bolts to ring anchors.
content.location: Seventh climb from left.

content.description:
High first bolt can be reached by stemming up corner.  Traverse in from right (5.11 b) to reach horizontal pockets.  Crux move up into left facing corner.   Direct start at low overhang (5.12) 

  The Chile Line was a narrow gauge rail that ran across the mesa above these climbs (west of Carson) from 1887 until 1941.  Frank Waters wrote about it in The Woman at Otowi Crossing
content.protection: 5 bolts to 2 bolt ring anchors
content.location: Bolted route right of Modest Mouse

content.description: Nice climbing with good gear.
content.protection: Small to medium gear.
content.location: Left side of the cliff. Short corner just right of obvious green slab. Rap from anchor or top out.

content.description: Crack climb right of Bolted (4) face climb at boulder field.
content.protection: Poor gear, needs cleaning and bolt, no anchor.
content.location: Crack above boulder field.

content.description:
Start of the thin, overhanging, black corner.  

  Getting past the third bolt is the crux. Sequential climbing at the start (V6 move) leads to a ledge and nice 5.10 climbing in the upper corner.  

  At the crux, strike hard and fast.
content.protection: Six clips lead to a two-bolt anchor.      To Toprope: You can access chain anchor from top of spilloff for the arroyo.
content.location: The very obvious, black corner 20 feet left of Modest Mouse.

content.description:
Right side of upper tier grassy ledge below and upstream of parking spot. Ignore all the traffic turning around. Bouldery start using layback crack at left and high right horizontal hold.  Move from wide stem to layback pinned flake at start (awkward crux) to blocks above (solid today).  Finish on right flare crack.   

  Named for the book by Ram Dass

en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Remem…(book)
content.protection: Start below high bolt (may need stick clip) to second bolt just over lip. 4 bolts total with Red and Gold Camalots in horizontal midway up to a final bolt on headwall.  2 bolt anchor with rings.  For toprope, anchors easily accessed  just upstream of juniper on edge.
content.location: Left of Mariposa

content.description:
Be Here Now 

ramdass.org/

en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ram_Dass

   Good pro in mixed quality rock, needs a good cleaning.
content.protection: Standard rack.  No top anchors, belay from boulders above (Gold camalot useful for top belay anchor).  I used double red and green on FA but not necessary.
content.location: Last crack on grassy ledge just upstream of Mariposa.

content.description: Cool little route with a mix of bolts and gear.
content.protection: Medium to small gear and five quickdraws for the bolts and anchor.
content.location: On the left side of the cliff. Obvious corner to a thin crack.

content.description:
A fun, positive right-angling crack with no feet leads up for about 10 feet to a wide slot and a decent stance. Despite the appearance you don't need big gear. Pull up and right out of the slot along the crack and then test your flexibility with a big leg stretch left to a good ledge and a rest. An all-too-short perfect hand crack goes up for eight feet to easier ground to the top and the tree for an anchor.  

  When Kit Carson passed away in May 1868, a month after his wife Josefa, his last words were "Adios Compadres".
content.protection: Single .5 to #2 camalots. Possibly doubles if you want to really sew it up.
content.location:
A few feet right of I Came As A Rat past a big roof. Look for the tree at the top that serves as the anchor. A sling and single locking biner on the tree provide the anchor. A flat rock with the number "10" spelled out using tiny rocks may be at the start.  

  Note that we *think* this route is left of Man in the Arena but we didn't find that route so we're not completely sure.  Just look for the big roof and tree and you'll be there.

content.description: Right of HA
content.protection: Gear

content.description: Right of HA
content.protection: Bolts

content.description: Short, steep cragging above the Rio Grande at the gorge rim. The first significant wall you come to after hiking along the rim from Dead Cholla. Some anchors easily accessed from the lip.
